sub_topic: Calculation of entropy change for a chemical reaction
message_1: Calculate the standard entropy change for the reaction of 2 moles of nitrogen gas reacting with 5 moles of oxygen gas to produce 2 moles of nitrogen monoxide gas at a constant pressure of 1 bar and 298 K. Given the standard molar entropy of nitrogen gas, oxygen gas, and nitrogen monoxide gas to be 191.6 J K-1 mol-1, 205.0 J K-1 mol-1, and 210.6 J K-1 mol-1, respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the standard entropy change (ΔS°) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔS° = ΣnS°(products) - ΣnS°(reactants)

where n is the stoichiometric coefficient and S° is the standard molar entropy of each species.

For the given reaction:

2 N₂(g) + 5 O₂(g) → 2 NO(g)

The standard entropy change is:

ΔS° = [2 moles × 210.6 J K-1 mol-1 (NO)] - [2 moles × 191.6 J K-1 mol-1 (N₂) + 5 moles × 205.0 J K-1 mol-1 (O₂)]

ΔS° = [421.2 J K-1] - [383.2 J K-1 (N₂) + 1025.0 J K-1 (O₂)]

ΔS° = 421.2 J K-1 - 1408.2 J K-1

ΔS° = -987.0 J K-1

The standard entropy change for the reaction is -987.0 J K-1.
